I understood everything about 'Moonlight', and yet the movie didn't excite me as much as I wanted it to be. I wanted to LIKE it, but I just found it boring. And now that I see this video, i can't help but be frustrated we don't get to see what happened to Juan or how Chiron got into prison. I feel there were things missing that could've helped - at least me anyway - connect to the film on an emotional level. I think what people liked about this movie is that they're so used to seeing and perceiving Black stereotypes that the image of Black boys being vulnerable is completely foreign. If seeing Black people as human and affectionate is this groundbreaking then I can't help but wonder how we were seen before this film. Glad it won an Oscar. I just wish it was worth the hype as far as story. I mean, hitting the bully with the chair got my attention and maybe the fight in the schoolyard too, but that was about it. Maybe I missed something else. I feel like I saw nothing new in this film, unfortunately.

SPOILERS

I think the ice and cold was significant as after him first using the ice pack in the office he first began to lean into his more closed and traditionally masculine behavior. And you notice that he goes and sticks his head back in the fridge in a scene in his 20’s. I think the cold is representative of him closing up and hardening while the beach represents the opposite for him as it’s at the beach where he opens up and makes himself more vulnerable. I love how this movie simply for the amount of symbolism and metaphors and whatnot to pick apart. I can’t personally relate to any of main topic the movie touches on as I’m straight and Native American, but i still found it to be incredibly compelling as a piece of art and even made me think more about theses things as it presents it in a not obnoxious way. It doesn’t feel like it’s just agenda-pushing propaganda as it just shows you all this stuff and lets you use your own mind to come to your own conclusions and judgements. Excellent movie.

I cried. Everyone I know in the hood cried. It's too much. This is more than a story. It's real life told in the most beautiful and intense way. The hermeneutics are insane too.

Notice that his name is spelled EXACTLY like the famous historical Greek Centaur Chiron, who was COMPLETELY different than his counterparts and fellow Centaurs.

Centaurs are known for violence and a lack of self control-Just like the cultural narrative of American black men.

However Chiron was different. Known for his bravery and knowledge. Chiron gained his benevolence from an absolutely HORRIBLE early life. Just like in moonlight; Chiron too had been abandoned by his mother, and soon adopted by the god Apollo.

In astrology the astroid named after Chiron; is representative of early childhood traumatic experiences and emotional growth from pain wrongfully inflicted on you.

I'm all for introspective movies and I like complex thought provoking films which break away from the norm. BUT, I didn't like moonlight. All these elements you explained WORKED for me when I saw it, but still, I couldn't enjoy it because
1) the dialogue wasn't great. It got the message across but that's about it.
2) I never connected with the main character. Maybe you were not supposed because that's what his character was all about, loneliness and lack of connection. But that means I'm an outsider looking in, and that greatly reduces my sympathy, and I just didn't really care all that much.
3)scenes were not as well crafted as it was made out to be. I mean, I don't remember half of what happened in the movie, I remember the themes but so many scenes were just "nothing" scenes. Again, I get that it's supposed to portray the more mundane side of life contrasted against the difficulties Chiron is facing, but because Chiron himself keeps his inner turmoil "inner" even to the audience, then all we see is the mundane life side of things.

It is good to see a movie with black and gay central characters, empowering. However, the movie's characters are unfortunately depicted as rather one-dimensional and the plot is just about non-existent. The problem is not that it is slow, that's fine, the problem is that it goes perfectly nowhere with its characters, no matter how gay or black they are. The first three quarters or so are excellently executed and full of promise and then it just...peters out.... Compare: The Embrace of the Serpent.

I saw the film in theatre/cinema back then, but it didn’t connect with me emotionally. Yes, the two younger versions of him acted very well, but there were too long pauses, the film had a very slow style and all characters were very tight-lipped. These things make it hard for me to get into the characters as I’m more of a rational and communicative person. Just film techniques and camera angles don’t make me feel things, I need the characters to more actively express their feelings. Am I a heartless robot? :) But I’m still touched by subtle, realistic acting - I don’t need things hammered home. The most powerful and touching scene was, therefore, the one between him and his mother in rehab. In general, I’d say she was the best adult actor in this movie.
Yes yes yes! An amazing and thorough analysis and I am greatly anticipating Beasts of No Nation in the next installment.

There's a great interview on Song Exploder about the soundtrack for this movie. Chyrone's theme when he's little is the basis of the score and then at each stage of his life the score is pitch shifted down to make it darker and more distorted, while still keeping the heart. It's a way of showing through sound that Chyrone might change on the outside, taking on signifiers in order to protect himself, but his core is unchanging. It makes me think of a matryoshka doll.
